questions.text: A patient in the ICU undergoing invasive monitoring with intra-arterial cannulation of the right radial artery for 3 days develops swelling and discolouration of the right hand. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient has developed vasospasm(reflex sympathetic dystrophy) as indicated by the development of swelling & discolouration of the hand
  • Stellate Block(Cervicothoracic sympathetic) blocks the upper thoracic and cervical ganglia. It is indicated in:
    • Reflex sympathetic dystrophy
    • Vasospastic disorder of the upper extremity
    • Head, Neck, Arm & Upper chest pain
  • Signs of successful stellate ganglion block include
    • Horner's syndrome
    • Muller's syndrome (injection of the tympanic membrane)
    • Guttman's sign (stuffy nose)
    • Conjunctiva congestion
    • Flushing of face
    • Lacrimation, etc (but not bradycardia)

Explanation of other options

Radial nerve block -(Option A): Provides sensory and motor blockade distal to the elbow but does not address sympathetic vasospasm.

Brachial plexus block -(Option B): Provides anaesthesia to the limb but does not selectively block the sympathetic fibres causing vasospasm.

Celiac plexus block -(Option D): Used for abdominal visceral pain, unrelated to upper extremity vasospasm.

Key Takeaways:

  • Vasospasm after arterial cannulation can lead to limb ischemia.
  • Stellate ganglion block is an effective intervention to reverse vasospasm by sympathetic blockade.
  • Horner's syndrome is a clinical marker of successful stellate ganglion block.

choices.text: No change in functional residual capacity (FRC)

questions.text: Which of the following is a physiological effect of Positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP)
questions.solution:
Explanation :

  • By increasing lung volume and improving alveolar recruitment, PEPP reduces the transpulmonary pressure required to inflate the lungs, hence reducing the work of breathing.

Explanation of other options:

Decreases FRC- Option (A): PEEP increases, not decreases, FRC. FRC is the volume of air remaining in the lungs at the end of passive expiration. By keeping alveoli open, PEEP increases this resting volume, improving oxygenation and reducing the risk of atelectasis. A decrease in FRC is associated with worsened oxygenation and lung collapse, which PEEP is designed to prevent.

Increases work of breathing (Option (B): PEEP typically reduces the work of breathing by preventing repetitive alveolar collapse and reopening, which is energy-consuming. However, inappropriately high PEEP can increase intrathoracic pressures, reduce venous return, and overdistend alveoli, potentially leading to increased effort and ventilator asynchrony—but in general, therapeutic levels of PEEP reduce the work of breathing.

No change in FRC (Option C): Even modest levels of PEEP increase FRC. The primary physiological mechanism of PEEP is to maintain alveolar patency, which directly increases lung volume at end-expiration. This improves ventilation-perfusion matching and gas exchange.

Key Takeaways:

  • PEEP increases FRC and reduces the work of breathing.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are correct
Both the assertion and the reason are wrong
The Assertion is correct, but the reason is wrong
The Assertion is wrong, but the reason is correct

questions.text:
Assertion: Mechanical ventilation works on a principle opposite to that of physiological ventilation
Reason: Mechanical ventilation is a positive-pressure ventilation
questions.solution:
Explanation :

  • Normal physiological respiration is a process in which negative pressures are generated inside the thoracic cavity during inspiration and expiration, which is a passive process. In contrast, mechanical ventilation involves positive pressure to inflate the lungs during inspiration. These are opposite mechanisms.
  • During positive pressure ventilation, gas flow is delivered to the lungs under a positive pressure gradient (i.e., airway pressure is greater than alveolar pressure).
  • When positive pressure is used for ventilation, the pressures in the airways, alveoli, and pleura are increased during inspiration.

questions.text: A 72-year-old patient with COPD exacerbation and respiratory distress is being managed in the ICU. The intensivist decides to initiate ventilatory support without using an artificial airway. Which of the following are/is a method of non-invasive mechanical ventilation
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Non-invasive ventilation (NIV) is defined as the delivery of ventilatory support without the use of an endotracheal tube or tracheostomy. It is used in conditions like COPD exacerbation, cardiogenic pulmonary oedema, and certain cases of hypoxemic respiratory failure.
  • CPAP (Continuous Positive Airway Pressure) delivers constant positive pressure throughout the respiratory cycle and improves oxygenation by recruiting alveoli.
  • BIPAP (Bilevel Positive Airway Pressure) delivers two levels of pressure: higher during inspiration (IPAP) and lower during expiration (EPAP), and is considered a form of NIV.
  • Non-rebreathing masks, however, do not constitute NIV as they deliver high concentrations of oxygen but do not provide positive pressure or ventilatory assistance.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old male with severe traumatic brain injury is admitted to the ICU with declining Glasgow Coma Scale and poor airway protection. The intensivist plans to initiate invasive mechanical ventilation.
Which of the following are acceptable methods for securing the airway in invasive ventilation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Invasive mechanical ventilation requires an artificial airway placed beyond the vocal cords, ensuring direct access to the lower airway and enabling positive-pressure ventilation.
  • Endotracheal intubation is the most commonly used method, especially for short- to intermediate-term airway management. (Option A ruled out)
  • Tracheostomy is generally used when prolonged ventilatory support is anticipated or when upper airway obstruction is present. (Option B ruled out)
  • Cricothyroidotomy is an emergency procedure used for rapid airway access in critical situations such as "can't intubate, can't ventilate."( Option C ruled out )

choices.text: It relies on active ventilation through high-pressure jet oxygen
It facilitates apneic oxygenation via high-flow humidified nasal oxygen.
It causes immediate alveolar collapse during apnea
It is contraindicated in all anticipated difficult airways.

questions.text: THRIVE is a recent mode of ventilation. Which of the following statements regarding THRIVE is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

THRIVE is a technique that provides high-flow oxygen (up to 70 L/min) via a nasal cannula. It supports apneic oxygenation by delivering continuous humidified and warmed oxygen during apnea.

  • It functions based on the concept of aventilatory mass flow (AVMF), where oxygenation continues during apnea as long as the airway is patent.
  • THRIVE significantly extends the safe apnea time, especially useful in anticipated difficult intubations.
  • It is not jet ventilation and does not cause alveolar collapse; rather, it improves oxygenation and delays desaturation.

Explanation of other options:

Option (A) Incorrect - THRIVE does not use high-pressure jet ventilation; it is a high-flow system, not a pressure-driven one.

Option (C) Incorrect-THRIVE delays alveolar collapse by prolonging oxygen delivery, not promoting collapse.

Option (D) Incorrect - THRIVE is often used in difficult airways to buy time and improve safety.

choices.text: It delivers cold, dry oxygen at low flow rates to reduce airway oedema.
It requires an endotracheal tube to deliver oxygen efficiently.
It provides warmed, humidified, high-flow oxygen via nasal cannula and offers noninvasive respiratory support.
It is contraindicated in patients with mild hypoxemia.

questions.text: HFNO(High-Flow Nasal Oxygen) is a newer method of ventilation gaining popularity in ICU settings. Which of the following statements about HFNO is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • High-Flow Nasal Oxygen (HFNO) delivers oxygen at high flow rates (up to 60 L/min) through specialised nasal cannula systems. It is being increasingly used in cases of respiratory failure, especially those that do not require immediate intubation.
  • It is considered a form of noninvasive respiratory support, not requiring an artificial airway.
  • HFNO delivers heated and humidified oxygen, which improves mucosal comfort, preserves ciliary function, and reduces airway drying.

Additional benefits include:

  • Washout of anatomical dead space
  • PEEP-like effect due to flow-dependent pressure generation

Explanation of other options:

Option (A) Incorrect - HFNO delivers warmed and humidified oxygen, not cold and dry gas.

Option (B) Incorrect - HFNO is a noninvasive technique, not delivered via an endotracheal tube.

Option (D) Incorrect - HFNO is indicated even in mild to moderate hypoxemia before escalation to invasive support.

questions.text: Use of mechanical ventilation in a patient is associated with risks and benefits.. The harmful effects of mechanical ventilation include
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Ventilator-Associated Lung Injury (VALI): Refers to injury caused by barotrauma, volutrauma, atelectrauma, or biotrauma due to excessive airway pressures or volumes. Closely linked to ARDS pathophysiology.
  • Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia (VAP): A nosocomial infection occurring after >48 hours of mechanical ventilation, often due to impaired airway defence mechanisms and biofilm formation on the endotracheal tube.
  • These complications are prominent concerns in long-term ventilated ICU patients.
  • Mechanical ventilation reduces, not increases, the work of breathing. ( Option D ruled out )

questions.text:
A 70-year-old male with severe ARDS is receiving volume-controlled mechanical ventilation in the ICU. Despite low tidal volume settings, the patient develops signs of worsening lung injury, with patchy infiltrates and increased inflammatory markers.
Which of the following mechanisms is most likely contributing to the development of ventilator-associated lung injury (VALI)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ventilator-associated lung injury (VALI) occurs due to multiple mechanical and cellular insults during mechanical ventilation, especially in patients with diseased lungs (like ARDS).

  • Barotrauma - injury due to excessive airway pressure; causes alveolar rupture and air leaks.
  • Atelectrauma - damage from repetitive opening and collapse of alveoli, leading to shear stress.
  • Biotrauma - inflammatory response triggered by mechanical stress, leading to cytokine release and cellular injury.
  • Volutrauma (from prior question explanation) - excessive lung stretch from high tidal volumes or strain.

These mechanisms collectively amplify lung injury, worsening oxygenation and promoting systemic inflammation.

choices.text: Endotracheal tube with small internal diameter.

questions.text:
A ventilated patient develops an increase in peak airway pressure. On evaluation, increased airway resistance is suspected.
Which of the following is least likely to contribute to increased airway resistance in this context?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Airway resistance refers to the opposition to airflow within the tracheobronchial tree and is influenced by factors such as airway diameter, secretions, and circuit patency.

  • Common contributors in ventilated patients include: Intrinsic disease (e.g., asthma, COPD, bronchiectasis)
  • Mechanical issues like small ETT diameter, circuit kinking, or condensation in ventilator (Option B and C ruled out )
  • Obstruction (e.g., mucus plug, foreign body, post-intubation narrowing) (Option A ruled out)
  • Tachycardia is a hemodynamic parameter and does not affect airway resistance directly.

choices.text: Increases the mechanical dead space on the ventilator circuit

questions.text:
A 60-year-old patient with neuromuscular weakness is on volume-controlled mechanical ventilation. A recent arterial blood gas (ABG) shows PaCO2 = 65 mm Hg. The patient is otherwise stable.
What is the most appropriate adjustment to improve ventilation?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Hypoventilation is indicated by elevated PaCO2, suggesting inadequate alveolar ventilation.
  • Minute ventilation (VE) is the product of tidal volume (Vt) and respiratory rate (Rr):
    VE=Vt ×Rr
  • To increase alveolar ventilation, you must increase minute ventilation.

Option C (increasing frequency) raises VE and reduces PaCO2

Explanation of other options:

Option (A): (Decrease the tidal volume) would worsen hypoventilation.

Option (B) :(Increase the mechanical dead space on the ventilator circuit) increases rebreathing of CO2.

Option (D) :(increasing FiOV2) improves oxygenation, not ventilation.

questions.text: A 50-year-old postoperative patient on minimal ventilatory support develops drowsiness and shallow breathing. Arterial blood gas reveals respiratory acidosis. Which of the following best characterises hypoventilation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hypoventilation is defined as a reduction in alveolar ventilation, leading to impaired carbon dioxide (CO2) elimination.
  • PaCO2 is inversely proportional to alveolar ventilation under steady-state CO2 production, hence, PaCO2 is increased.

Explanation of other options :

Option (A): PaO2 may decrease due to reduced oxygen exchange.

Option (B): When ventilation decreases, PaCO2 rises, resulting in respiratory acidosis (i.e., decreased pH, not increased).

choices.text: Low partial pressure of inspired oxygen

questions.text: Which of the following causes of hypoxemia is least likely to show improvement with administration of supplemental oxygen alone?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hypoxemia can arise from multiple mechanisms: hypoventilation, V/Q mismatch, diffusion limitation, low inspired oxygen pressure, and intrapulmonary shunt.
  • Among these, intrapulmonary shunting is unique because oxygen therapy alone is minimally
  • In shunt physiology, blood passes through non-ventilated alveoli, meaning even high FiO2 does not improve oxygenation effectively.
  • The definitive correction of shunt-related hypoxemia often requires strategies such as PEEP or CPAP to recruit collapsed alveoli and reestablish gas exchange.

Explanation of Other options:

Option (A): In hypoventilation, there is a global reduction in alveolar ventilation. This leads to elevated PaCO2 and decreased PaO2 (hypoxemia).

The alveoli are still open and perfused, so increasing the FiO2 increases the alveolar oxygen partial pressure (PAO2).

Option(B): Supplemental oxygen increases the PAO2 in under-ventilated alveoli, thereby improving oxygen diffusion in regions with low V/Q ratios.

Option (D): The problem is simply low oxygen delivery to the alveoli, not a defect in gas exchange or perfusion.

Increasing the FiO2 restores the driving gradient for oxygen diffusion.

questions.text: A neonate is being ventilated using pressure-controlled ventilation. The delivered tidal volume appears to be insufficient. What is the most appropriate ventilator setting adjustment to increase the tidal volume?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In pressure-controlled ventilation (PCV), the tidal volume is primarily determined by the peak inspiratory pressure set on the ventilator.
  • Increasing the pressure setting allows a greater pressure gradient between the airway and alveoli, thus delivering a larger tidal volume.

Explanation of Other options:

Option (A): In pressure-controlled ventilation, tidal volume is not set directly but is determined by the set pressure, compliance of the lung, and airway resistance.

Option ( C): Decreasing inspiratory flow may prolong inspiratory time, but does not increase tidal volume in pressure-controlled modes. It could lead to inadequate ventilation if the inspiratory time becomes too short to reach target pressures.

Option (D): Reducing inspiratory time may limit the time allowed for achieving peak inspiratory pressure, especially in lungs with poor compliance.This results in lower tidal volume, not higher.

questions.text: A 64-year-old postoperative patient in the ICU on mechanical ventilation begins to exhibit headache, drowsiness, and irritability. Arterial blood gas analysis reveals elevated PaCO2 and decreased PaO2. These symptoms are most likely due to involvement of which of the following systems?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Neurologic effects such as headache, drowsiness, and irritability often result from hypoxemia and hypercapnia, which cause cerebral vasodilation and increased intracranial pressure.

Carbon dioxide (COâ‚‚) retention is a potent cerebral vasodilator. It leads to increased cerebral blood flow and intracranial pressure, particularly during sleep.

Mental status changes due to ventilatory failure can range from subtle (irritability, forgetfulness) to severe (stupor, coma).

Explanation of Other options:

Option (A): Renal: Although renal failure can cause uremic encephalopathy, it typically presents with nausea, confusion, and seizures rather than isolated CO2 retention symptoms.

Option (B): Nutritional: Deficiencies (e.g., thiamine) cause neurologic symptoms over a longer course and are unrelated to ventilatory gas exchange.

Option ( C): Hepatic: Hepatic encephalopathy also causes altered mentation but is linked to elevated ammonia, not CO2 retention or ventilatory failure.)

questions.text: A mode of ventilation that augments a patient's spontaneous tidal volume with a preset level of pressure is called:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Pressure Support Ventilation (PSV) is a spontaneous mode in which each breath is initiated by the patient and augmented by a preset level of pressure to overcome airway resistance and endotracheal tube impedance.
  • PSV improves patient comfort, enhances spontaneous tidal volume, and reduces the work of breathing (WOB)
  • It is frequently used in the weaning phase of mechanical ventilation and is often combined with SIMV (Synchronised Intermittent Mandatory Ventilation).

Explanation of other options:

Option (A) :Pressure-controlled: Delivers preset pressure with each mandatory breath, not patient-initiated breaths; used in sedated or paralysed patients.

Option (C): Pressure limit: Refers to a safety feature that caps peak pressure but does not define a ventilation mode.

Option (D): Volume-controlled: Delivers a fixed tidal volume regardless of the patient's effort, and does not assist spontaneous breaths.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man is admitted to the ICU for neuromuscular respiratory failure. He is placed on a ventilator mode in which all breaths are controlled by the ventilator, and the patient does not initiate any breaths.
questions.solution:
Explanation :

  • Full ventilatory support is provided when the ventilator assumes total control of a patient's ventilation, typically in a controlled mode, such as volume-controlled ventilation (VCV) or pressure-controlled ventilation (PCV).
  • In these modes, breaths are delivered at a preset frequency and volume or pressure, regardless of the patient’s spontaneous effort. This is essential when the patient has no spontaneous respiratory drive (e.g., paralysis, deep sedation, or coma).

Explanation of Other options:

Option (A): Partial ventilatory support: In this mode, the ventilator assists some but not all breaths, and the patient retains some respiratory effort (e.g., SIMV or PSV).

Option (B): Incomplete ventilatory support: This term is not conventionally used in mechanical ventilation classification and is not recognised in standard nomenclature.

Option (D): No ventilatory support: This applies to patients breathing entirely spontaneously without any support from a ventilator, irrelevant in a mechanically ventilated ICU patient.

questions.text: Positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) is most commonly used to correct which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) increases the pressure in the lungs at the end of expiration, preventing alveolar collapse and improving oxygenation.
  • It is particularly effective in treating refractory hypoxemia, where oxygenation does not improve despite high inspired oxygen concentration (FiO2).
  • By recruiting collapsed alveoli and improving ventilation-perfusion matching, PEEP enhances arterial oxygenation.

Explanation of other options:

Hypercapnia (Option A): PEEP does not primarily address elevated carbon dioxide levels; it may sometimes worsen hypercapnia by increasing dead space.

Mild hypoxemia (Option C): Mild hypoxemia often responds to supplemental oxygen alone without the need for PEEP.

Respiratory acidosis (Option D): Respiratory acidosis is related to inadequate ventilation and CO2 retention, not primarily treated by PEEP.

questions.text: When PEEP (Positive end-expiratory pressure) is applied to the airway of a spontaneously breathing patient, what is this mode called?:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • PEEP applied to spontaneously breathing patients maintains a positive pressure in the airways throughout the respiratory cycle, preventing alveolar collapse and improving oxygenation.
  • When this positive pressure is provided continuously during spontaneous breathing without ventilator-delivered breaths, it is termed Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP).
  • CPAP is commonly used to treat hypoxemia and improve lung mechanics in patients breathing spontaneously.

Explanation of Other options:

Airway pressure release ventilation (Option A): This is a mode of mechanical ventilation that alternates between two levels of continuous positive airway pressure to facilitate ventilation. It is not applied solely during spontaneous breathing.

Pressure support ventilation (Option C): This mode assists spontaneous breaths by providing positive pressure only during inspiration, not throughout the respiratory cycle.

Pressure-controlled ventilation (Option D): A controlled mechanical ventilation mode where breaths are delivered at a preset pressure regardless of spontaneous effort.

questions.text: Which of the following clotting factors has the shortest half-life?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Factor VII is one of the four vitamin K-dependent clotting factors (factors II, VII, IX, and X).
  • It also has the shortest half-life of all the clotting factors (4-6 hours) and is the first factor to become deficient in patients with severe hepatic failure, warfarin (Coumadin) anticoagulation therapy, and vitamin K deficiency.
  • The prothrombin time (PT) is particularly sensitive to decreases in Factor VII.

Explanation of other options:-

Option(A)- Factor II (Prothrombin): Has a longer half-life (~60 hours) and decreases later in liver disease or warfarin therapy.

Option(B) -Factor V: Not vitamin K-dependent and has a moderate half-life (~12-36 hours).

Option(D)- Factor IX: Vitamin K-dependent but with a longer half-life (~20-30 hours) than Factor VII.

Key Takeaways:

  • Vitamin K-dependent factors are II, VII, IX, and X.
  • Monitoring PT is essential in managing patients on anticoagulants or with liver dysfunction.

choices.text: Use of blood less than 14 days old

questions.text: Which of the following measures does NOT reduce the incidence of transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI)?
questions.solution:
• TRALI typically occurs within 6 hours of transfusion and presents as noncardiogenic pulmonary oedema with bilateral infiltrates and hypoxemia. The pathophysiology involves antibody-mediated and neutrophil activation mechanisms.
  • Leukocyte reduction, while reducing febrile transfusion reactions and CMV transmission, does not significantly reduce the incidence of TRALI because leukocytes are not the primary mediators.

Explanation of other options:

Exclusion of female donors (Option A): Reduces TRALI incidence by limiting donor antibodies.

Use of autologous (Option B): Eliminates the risk of immune-mediated TRALI.Because the donor and recipient are the same person, there are no alloantibodies (like anti-HLA or anti-HNA) involved.
Therefore, the immune mismatch mechanism that triggers TRALI cannot occur.

Use of blood less than 14 days old (Option D): Limits the accumulation of biologically active mediators implicated in TRALI.

Key Takeaways:

TRALI is a serious transfusion complication caused by donor antibodies and neutrophil activation.

choices.text: It reduces the chance for infection
It decreases the incidence of allergic reactions

questions.text: rationale for the storage of platelets at room temperature (22° C) is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • At a pH below 6.0 or in cold temperatures such as 4° C (the temperature used for blood storage), platelets undergo irreversible shape changes.
  • The optimal temperature for platelet storage is 22° C ± 2° C, or room temperature. There are two major problems with platelet storage at this recommended temperature.
    • First, the pH falls because of platelet metabolism.
    • Second, bacterial growth is possible, which could potentially lead to sepsis and death. To minimise these problems, platelet storage is limited to 5 days at 22° C

Explanation of other options:

Less splenic sequestration (Option A): Not the primary reason for room temperature storage.

Reduced infection risk (Option C): Room temperature storage increases bacterial growth risk.

Decreased allergic reactions (Option D): Not related to storage temperature effects on platelets.

questions.text: Hetastarch exerts an anticoagulative effect through interference with the function of;
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hetastarch (hydroxyethyl starch) is a colloid solution used for intravascular volume expansion. It is known to interfere with coagulation primarily by reducing the activity and levels of Factor VIII and von Willebrand factor.
  • This interference contributes to a mild anticoagulant effect, increasing bleeding risk in patients receiving large volumes of hetastarch. Unlike dextran, hetastarch does not interfere with blood crossmatching.

Explanation of other options:

Antithrombin III (Option A): No significant interference by hetastarch.

Fibrinogen (Option C): Not primarily affected by hetastarch.

Prostacyclin (Option D): Not involved in hetastarch's anticoagulant mechanism

questions.text: What is the storage life of whole blood stored with citrate phosphate dextrose (CPD)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Many preservation solutions are used for whole blood and RBCs. Acid citrate dextrose, CPD, and citrate phosphate double dextrose (CP2D) each allow blood to have a shelf life of 21 days.
  • In 1978, the FDA approved the additive adenine to CPD. This extended the shelf life of blood by 2 weeks. CPDA-1 has a shelf life of 35 days.
  • By use of an additive solution (which contains primarily adenine, glucose, and saline) to the CPD or CP2D whole blood that has the plasma removed, the packed RBCs can now be stored for 42 days. The three different additive solutions currently used in the United States are Adsol (AS-1), Nutricel (AS-3), and Optisol (AS-5)

(Options A, C and D ruled out)

questions.text: The most common cause of mortality associated with the administration of blood is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) is the leading cause of transfusion-related mortality.
  • It typically presents within 6 hours of transfusion with acute respiratory distress, bilateral pulmonary infiltrates, and hypoxemia in the absence of circulatory overload or cardiac dysfunction.

Explanation of other options :

Non-ABO hemolytic transfusion reaction (Option B): Less frequent cause of death than TRALI.

Microbial infection (Option C): Though serious, less common due to strict screening and bacterial detection protocols.

Anaphylactic reaction (Option D): Rare and not a leading cause of transfusion-related mortality.

choices.text: Decreased venous return to the heart
Increased afterload on the right side of the heart
Increased afterload on the left side of the heart

questions.text: A 67-year-old patient is mechanically ventilated in the ICU 2 days after repair of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. To maintain Pao2 in the 60 to 65 range, 10 cm H2O positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) is added to the ventilator cycle. The patient's blood pressure averaged 110/65 before the addition of PEEP. After the addition of PEEP, the blood pressure is noted to slowly fall to an average of approximately 95/50. The best explanation for this decrease in blood pressure is
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • PEEP increases intrathoracic pressure, which reduces venous return to the heart (preload). This results in decreased left ventricular filling and stroke volume, ultimately lowering cardiac output and systemic arterial pressure.
  • This hemodynamic effect is more pronounced in hypovolemic patients or those with limited cardiac reserve. Thus, a fall in blood pressure after PEEP application is primarily due to reduced venous return and not due to direct cardiac afterload effects.

Explanation of other Options:

Tension pneumothorax (Option A): Though it can also cause hypotension, it presents with the sudden onset of respiratory and hemodynamic compromise and is less likely in this controlled PEEP setting.

Increased right-sided afterload (Option C): PEEP may increase pulmonary vascular resistance, but this does not primarily account for the systemic hypotension seen here.

Increased left-sided afterload (Option D): Not typically caused by PEEP.

Key Takeaways:

PEEP can impair venous return and reduce cardiac output.

Hypotension due to PEEP is most often preload-related.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a component of the postanesthetic discharge scoring system (PADSS) used to evaluate the suitability of a patient to be discharged from an ambulatory surgical facility?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Postanesthetic Discharge Scoring System (PADSS) is used to objectively determine whether a patient can be safely discharged from an ambulatory surgical facility. It includes five essential criteria:

  • Vital signs [Systolic blood pressure (SBP), Diastolic blood pressure (DBP), Heart rate (HR)]
  • Activity (ambulation)
  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Pain control
  • Surgical bleeding

Drinking fluids or voiding before discharge is not a required component of PADSS, as these are considered controversial and not evidence-based criteria for readiness.

Explanation of other options:

Minimal surgical bleeding (Option B): Included in PADSS.

Absence of nausea and vomiting (Option C): Important for ensuring patient stability post-anaesthesia.

Pain control (Option D): Adequate analgesia is a core requirement for discharge readiness.

questions.text: A 31-year-old patient has been in the ICU on a ventilator for 24 hours after a motor vehicle accident. The patient does not open his eyes to any stimulus and has no verbal or motor response. What is the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score corresponding to this clinical condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is used to assess neurologic function in critically ill or head-injured patients. It has three components:

  • Eye-opening (4 points max)
  • Verbal response (5 points max)
  • Motor response (6 points max)

Each category is scored based on patient response. A score of 1 in each domain (no response) is the lowest possible, totalling GCS 3.

In this patient, the absence of eye opening, verbal, and motor response indicates a GCS of 3, which signifies deep coma or brain death and is the lowest possible score on the scale.

(Options A, B and C ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • The minimum total score on the GCS is 3 (1 point per domain).
  • GCS is a key tool in ICU and trauma assessment.
  • GCS 3 indicates deep coma or no neurological activity.
